primair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: God addresses the cosmic condition of sin by condemning it in the flesh of His Son, thereby redeeming humanity from a curse they cannot escape themselves.

tekstueel_bewijs: Sending his own Son... [God] condemned sin in the flesh.
God made him to be sin who knew no sin.
Christ redeemed us from the curse of the law.
that in him we might become the righteousness of God
that we might die to sin and live to righteousness

zender.identificatie: God the Father / The Holiness of the Law
tekstueel_bewijs: Christ redeemed us from the curse of the law
for my broken self and your broken self
having become a curse for us
He himself bore our sins in his body

tegenstander.identificatie: Sin (as a Power), Death, and the Curse
tekstueel_bewijs: a powerful force that grips us beyond the sovereignty of our wills
tegenstander.toelichting_ernst: Sin is defined not as misdeeds but as a condition/force that overrides human will, requiring a divine Subject to overcome.

secundair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: The believer's response to the Gospel: identifying with the 'God-damned' status and showing radical grace to others.
secundair_narratief_programma.subject: The Christian (e.g., Will Campbell)
secundair_narratief_programma.object: Solidarity with both victim and victimizer
secundair_narratief_programma.toelichting_verhouding: The secondary program (ethics) is presented as a 'parable' or consequence of the primary program (soteriology).

voorbeelden_god_subject: God condemned sin in the flesh.
God made him to be sin.
voorbeelden_mens_subject: I glanced around, looking for police.
We want to believe in innocence.
I put my own wishes ahead of the common good.

voorbeelden: Ash Wednesday is a day set apart especially for corporate repentance
We want to believe in innocence.
This helps us to understand the hideous shamefulness of crucifixion.
By a miracle of God’s undeserved grace I swerved.

modale_analyse.modale_interpretatie: The sermon emphasizes human 'non-pouvoir' (inability) and God's 'pouvoir' (sovereign power) to save.

semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.beweging_in_preek: From ~S2 (denial of sin) to S2 (the reality of the curse) to S1 (Christ becoming the curse to bring grace).
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.theologische_resolutie: Substitutionary atonement: Christ occupies S2 so the Receiver can occupy S1.
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.ernst_van_s2: Extremely high; the curse is described as 'God-damned' and 'subhuman'.

diagnostische_evaluatie.classificatie_toelichting: The sermon is profoundly theocentric. It defines sin as a power beyond human control and places the agency of salvation entirely on God's action in Christ.

indicatoren_moralisme.tekstueel_bewijs: Will Campbell... has been for many years a living parable.

indicatoren_genade.tekstueel_bewijs: God made him to be sin who knew no sin.
a powerful force that grips us beyond the sovereignty of our wills

exemplarisme_check.beschrijving: Will Campbell is used as a 'parable' of the Gospel, not a moral hero to be imitated by human effort.
exemplarisme_check.alternatieve_lezing: The sermon already treats figures theocentrically.

identificatie_patroon.effect_op_hoorder: Relief and humility; realization of total dependence on grace.

narratieve_coherentie.coherentie_beschrijving: The narrative moves seamlessly from the human predicament to the divine solution.

soteriologie.tekstueel_bewijs: Christ redeemed us from the curse... having become a curse for us.

pneumatologie.competentie_schenking: The sermon focuses on the work of the Son; the Spirit's role is implied in the 'transformation'.

aanbevelingen.actantiele_audit_samenvatting: The sermon perfectly aligns with the Greimassian model of grace: God is the Subject, Sin is the Heavy Opponent, and the Hearer is the Receiver.

modale_balans.concrete_suggestie: The lack of 'Devoir' (duty) is appropriate for a sermon focusing on the 'Ash Wednesday' / Lenten reality of the Cross.

aanbevelingen.slotopmerking: This sermon is a masterclass in theocentric preaching. It avoids the trap of moralism by refusing to make the hearer the subject of their own salvation or even their own repentance.

comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_retorische_analyse: Rhetorical analysis might focus on the 'shock value' of the title; Greimas shows the title is a literal structural description of the actantial state of the Receiver.
comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_exegese: Exegesis explains the Greek of Galatians; Greimas shows how that verse functions as the 'engine' of the entire sermon's logic.
comparatieve_analyse.unieke_inzichten_greimas: Reveals that the 'Will Campbell' story is not a moral exhortation but a semiotic 'parable' that mirrors the primary actantial movement of Christ.

appendices.notities: The sermon successfully uses a 'Heavy Opponent' to necessitate a 'Divine Subject'.
